woman comes from Indonesia to a US diplomat who lives in the DC area and
the diplomat brings her in on a legitimate visa she flies here to the US she thinks that she's me working for the
diplomat taking care of kids and and caring for an elderly parent and working in the home as a domestic worker and
then when she gets here she gets her passport confiscated she is forced
against her will to be in the home almost permanently she has to stay awake and get woken up throughout the night

US citizen kid growing up in foster care and she has been bouncing around to
about 20 different foster homes and she was removed from her home because there
was sexual abuse and neglect in that home now she's in foster care and living

with this US citizen sex trafficker meanwhile there's this boy coming to the
u.s. from Guatemala he's fleeing violence in Guatemala he gets to the border traveling by himself

contract crews servicing chicken poultry processing and turkey processing and egg
farms and all of a sudden this 14 year old Guatemalan kid finds himself being forced on to this contract crew in Iowa
and meanwhile there's a woman from Thailand who gets recruited by telling

drives her to one of these local massage parlors in the LA area where guys are going in and buying sex and she's stuck
in that situation for the next few years being sold for sex under threat and under violence and then that case
ultimately resolves in this federal bus that happens right so think about that
four different cases one we're talking about a woman who's an adult woman foreign national held in a home then
we're talking about a US citizen kid under the control of a sex trafficker then we're talking about this Guatemalan
boy who's at these Iowa egg farms right and then we're talking about this Thai woman who's in this massage parlor all
those were federal human trafficking cases that broke over the past couple years so none of that was kind of made

the sex trade and it happens in people forced into different types of labor industries it happens on legitimate

issue is much much larger than most city officials realize most state government
official realize and most people kind of in our day-to-day real day-to-day lives realize so the definition of human
trafficking just so you all understand is three buckets the first bucket is kids involved in the commercial sex
trade any child age 17 or younger being exploited in the commercial sex trade the second bucket is you take the
broader view of the overall sex trade what is the subset of the sex trade of people who are held there through force
fraud or coercion who are adults and then the third bucket are all the forms
of labor trafficking out there kids and adults anyone in some sort of job where
there's force or fraud or coercion keeping them there so one bucket for child sex trafficking one bucket for
adult sex trafficking and one bucket for all the types of labor trafficking those are defined in this federal law called
the trafficking Victims Protection Act so Polaris was founded as an organization that specifically works on
this issue we work on all forms of trafficking and we started here in the
United States eventually expanding more globally we've been doing this work for about 17 years
the estimate is that when you add up those three buckets of how many globally
how many kids are in the sex trade about two million globally how many adults are
in the sex trade by force fraud or coercion globally how many people are forced to work against their will you
add up those three buckets the total number is about 25 million that number came out last year and then you would

controlling and exploiting other people for profit right that's a that's a good
way to think about human trafficking not notions of movement not notions of transportation not not notions of border
crossing really notions of exploitation and voluntary servitude right so there's
150 billion dollar criminal industry and the traffickers right now they know that there's this huge criminal response to

risk which is why this is a preferred crime of different transnational organized crime organizations and also

we work on about 20 new calls or about 30 new cases per day it's about 11,000

cases and the 50,000 cases we then have this major data set which is one of the
largest data sets on trafficking in the country and we're analyzing that data set for patterns and trends and we're

where this is happening what are the industries where this is happening Howard traffickers evolving right as we

here's how traffickers use rod sharing services here's how traffickers use social media to recruit here so

businesses that can play a major role in the fight against trafficking if they
are willing to say our products and services might being you might be being
used for this and we want to take a stand against it right I've been doing this work for 17 years and I remember
